A House committee has approved a measure to resume selling off federal lands across the West to people with mining claims.
The provision would lift a moratorium on land sales that's been in place for 12 years.
And as NPR's Elizabeth Shogren reports, it could make it easier than it has been in decades for companies and individuals to buy federal lands and turn them into mines or vacation resorts.
Fifteen years ago, Clay Thorne was tromping around the saguaro cactuses in red rock formations of Tonto National Forest near Phoenix.
He discovered gypsum.
It's a white quartz-looking material and very soft.
It's what you make wallboard out of.
In the gypsum were fine grains of gold and silver.
Using an 1872 law that's still in effect, he laid claim to more than 3,500 acres of land and applied to buy it for $2.50 an acre.
He was just in time.
A few years later, Congress put a moratorium on new applications by miners to buy federal land.
I think that I have done everything that's required by the government to get the land.
I've spent my money.
I've prospected it.
I staked it out.
And I filed the right proper paperwork.
I paid the fees.
But the sale has been held up because government says the land Thorne wants doesn't have enough gypsum on it to support a profitable mine.
Thorne disagrees and he's appealing their decision.
We have a series of bureaucratic people who are you might say trying to take it away from us.

If the new proposal now pending in Congress becomes law, people like Thorne will again be able to buy large swaths of federal land across the West, but the price will go up to a thousand dollars an acre or the market price, whichever is higher.
It's still controversial.
Critics say the provision is written so broadly that the government would be forced to sell even when people trying to buy the land can't show that mining would be profitable there.
This would go back to the days of the robber barons, of selling off our prime public lands to real estate developers and mining companies.
Roger Flynn is a pro-environmental lawyer who specializes in mining issues and teaches law at the University of Colorado.
With a little bit of paperwork and some field activity, you can go out, anyone, a United States citizen, including corporations, and buy public lands.
Republican congressional staffers say the provision won't provoke large land grabs.
They also say it's important to allow these sales to help local communities.
Right now when a mine on public land closes, any development has to be removed, but if the land were privately owned, any facilities could be used to provide jobs.
Carol Raulston of the National Mining Association says this is only fair.
That gives me chills every single time I read it.
And it's true.

For the next two weeks, we can expect a flurry of activity at the Supreme Court.
It's been a slow term so far, but some of the biggest cases will be announced by the end of the month.
Joining us now is Dahlia Lithwick.
She's legal analyst for DAY TO DAY and for the online magazine Slate.
Hi, Dahlia.
Hi, Madeleine.
So there are several big cases still to be decided.
Which one is the most important?

I think the one everybody really is going to take as a sort of bellwether is a very, very fraught case that the court has been holding on to for a long time about whether public elementary and secondary schools can use race when they assign students to their schools.
You know, it's sort of a hybrid of the affirmative action cases and the, you know, the legacy of the old desegregation cases.
And it's just going to tell us a terrific amount about what this new court is and where it's going.
It may or may not have very profound things to say about a very recently decided affirmative action case that came out of Michigan only a few years ago.
And so I think that's the case everybody is looking to see, you know, which way is the Roberts court going on this is a very crucial question of affirmative action.
Okay.
So we'll be looking for that one.
What about the other major cases?
Well, there's some big speech cases that are really interesting.
One is a major campaign finance reform case that's going to test whether grassroots lobby groups can air sort of very political ads right before elections.
And that's a speech case.
There's another free speech case that we've talked about before that has to do with whether the phrase, quote, ""bong hits for Jesus"" is protected student speech in a school speech context.
And then there's a very interesting case about whether the act of merely being a taxpayer would give you standing to sue President Bush over of his faith-based initiatives program.
So these are sort of all different sort of First Amendment-y cases that we're going to, again, get some real guidance about where the court is headed.
Well, we only have a couple of weeks left in the term.
What are some of the big themes that you've seen so far?
You know, it's interesting.

I think that in the big, big blockbuster cases we've seen so far - I'm thinking about the global warming case that came down recently, the partial-birth abortion case that was recently decided, cases about the size of jury awards, the ability of workers to sue their bosses for sex discrimination, what you though over and over again - and you'll remember we predicted this last year with 5-4 splits and every single time Justice Anthony Kennedy is right there as the fifth vote.
So I think it's very fair to say at this point, a year later, this is, you know, Anthony's Kennedy's court.
The other, I think, trend and theme that we're starting to see, and it really emerged in the last couple of months, is that this is a real ideologically riven court.
I mean we really do, depending on which side Anthony Kennedy takes, see a court that's quite, quite split on right/left lines.
And not just a shift in terms of how split it is, but a real shift in terms of tone and language, Madeleine.

We're seeing very, very strong words from the new Chief Justice Roberts in some cases - extremely strong and upset dissents from Ruth Bader Ginsburg, dissents, you'll remember, that she sometimes reads from the bench, which doesn't happen all that much.
So I think we're starting to see a court that sort of - the center isn't quite holding.
There's a lot of, I think, ideological tension there.

And I think the other big trend we're staring to see, it's fair to say, is a dramatic shift to the right, which is to say that even though Anthony Kennedy is that fifth swing vote, I don't think anyone disputes anymore that with the replacement of Sandra Day O'Conner by Samuel Alito, the court has quite dramatically, I think, become a much more conservative court.
Dahlia Lithwick of the online magazine Slate.
Thank you.
Always a pleasure.
